modules.title: Introduction to Computer and Computer Arithmetic
topics: Von Neumann and Harvard architectures – structure and comparison
Difference between computer organization and computer architecture
Instruction format and various addressing modes
Arithmetic operations: addition and subtraction with signed magnitude representation
Half adder, full adder, ripple carry adder, and carry look-ahead adder
Multiplication and division algorithms for binary numbers
Floating-point number representation and IEEE 754 standard
Design principles of Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU)

modules.title: Memory Organization and I/O Techniques
topics: Properties of inclusion, coherence, and locality in memory hierarchy
Memory hierarchy concepts and organization
Cache memory organization and design considerations
Cache replacement policies and techniques to reduce cache misses
Virtual memory organization: mapping and management techniques
I/O organization: modes of data transfer, handshaking mechanism, and Direct Memory Access (DMA)

modules.title: Pipeline and Instruction Level Parallelism (ILP)
topics: Quantitative techniques in computer design
Introduction to pipelining and stages of instruction pipeline
Arithmetic and processor pipelining concepts
Pipeline hazards: types, causes, and countermeasures
Advanced pipeline architectures: super-pipeline, superscalar, and Very Long Instruction Word (VLIW) systems
Introduction to Instruction Level Parallelism (ILP) and techniques to enhance ILP
Overview of array and vector processors

modules.title: Multiprocessor Architecture and Control Unit
topics: Taxonomy of parallel architectures and types of multiprocessor systems
Multi-cache inconsistency and coherence problems
Centralized and distributed shared memory architectures
Memory consistency models and cluster computer design
Data flow architecture concepts
RISC and CISC architectural comparison
Control Unit design: Hardwired and Microprogrammed control units – working principles

books: John L. Hennessy and David A. Patterson, “Computer Architecture: A Quantitative Approach”.
Hwang and Briggs, “Computer Architecture and Parallel Processing”.
M. M. Mano, “Computer System Architecture”, PHI.
courseOutcomes: Categorize the types of instructions and addressing modes and analyze their impact on processor design.
Demonstrate the design principles of arithmetic and logical units of a digital computer system.
Analyze cache memory performance and optimization techniques to reduce access time.
Explain paging, segmentation, and virtual memory management strategies.
Illustrate pipeline design and techniques to minimize hazards during instruction execution.
Understand concepts of parallel processing, multiprocessor architectures, and control unit design.

modules.title: Introduction and Divide & Conquer Techniques
topics: Properties and characteristics of algorithms
Patterns in algorithm design and their significance
Time and space complexity of algorithms
Asymptotic notations – Big O, Omega, and Theta and their mathematical significance
Master theorem and generating functions for recurrence relations
Divide and Conquer method: principle, steps, and complexity analysis
Binary Search algorithm and its complexity
Merge Sort and Quick Sort algorithms with analysis
Matrix multiplication algorithms – Strassen’s method
Heaps and heap operations: maintaining the heap property, building a heap
Heapsort algorithm and its efficiency
Priority queues and their applications
Lower Bound Theory: O(n log n) bound for comparison-based sorting
Set manipulation algorithms – UNION-FIND and related operations

modules.title: Graph Algorithms and Greedy Method
topics: Introduction to graph theory and graph traversal algorithms
Breadth-First Search (BFS) and Depth-First Search (DFS)
Best-First Search and Bidirectional Search techniques
Greedy method: basic approach and characteristics
Fractional Knapsack problem and its solution using greedy technique
Job sequencing with deadlines and cost optimization
Minimum cost spanning tree algorithms: Prim’s and Kruskal’s methods
Dijkstra’s algorithm for single-source shortest path determination

modules.title: Dynamic Programming and Network Flow
topics: Dynamic programming: concept, methodology, and advantages
All-pairs shortest path problem using dynamic programming
Single-source shortest path using Bellman-Ford algorithm
Matrix chain multiplication and optimization strategy
Travelling Salesperson Problem (TSP) and its dynamic programming solution
Network flow problems and optimization
Ford-Fulkerson algorithm for maximum flow computation
Max-Flow Min-Cut theorem – statement and illustration

modules.title: Backtracking, Branch and Bound, NP-Completeness, and Approximation Algorithms
topics: Backtracking method and applications
8-Queens problem and its recursive backtracking solution
Graph coloring problem and constraints handling
Branch and Bound method: principle and implementation
15-Puzzle problem using Branch and Bound approach
Notion of NP-Completeness and computational complexity classes
P, NP, NP-hard, and NP-complete classes – definitions and interrelationships
Cook’s theorem (statement only)
Satisfiability (SAT) problem and Clique decision problem
Non-deterministic algorithms and their relevance
Approximation algorithms: necessity and basic design principles
Polynomial-time approximation schemes (PTAS)
Travelling Salesman Problem (TSP) approximation algorithms

E. Horowitz and S. Sahni, “Fundamentals of Computer Algorithms”.
referenceBooks: A. Aho, J. Hopcroft, and J. Ullman, “The Design and Analysis of Algorithms”.

courseOutcomes: Analyze the time and space complexity of algorithms using asymptotic notations.
Distinguish between algorithms to solve optimization problems effectively.
Illustrate suitable algorithmic techniques for solving decision-making problems.
Apply algorithmic techniques to solve mathematical puzzles and logical problems.
Describe NP-hard and NP-complete problems and justify the need for approximation algorithms.
Develop efficient algorithms for solving common engineering and computational problems.

modules.title: Socio-Environmental Impact
topics: Basic ideas of environment and its components

Concepts of natural resources and sustainable development

Pollutants and contaminants in air

topics: Hydrosphere and its significance

Pesticides and salts as water pollutants
Biochemical effects of heavy metals on aquatic systems
Eutrophication: sources, effects, and control methods
Water quality parameters: DO (Dissolved Oxygen), BOD (Biochemical Oxygen Demand), COD (Chemical Oxygen Demand)

modules.title: Land and Noise Pollution
topics: Land pollution: sources, effects, and control measures

Noise pollution: definition and classification
Noise parameters – frequency, pressure, intensity, loudness, and threshold limit values

Control measures and mitigation strategies for noise pollution

courseOutcomes: Understand the natural environment and its relationship with human activities.
Characterize and analyze the impacts of human actions on the environment.
Integrate facts, concepts, and methods from multiple disciplines to address environmental problems.

Implement scientific research strategies for the collection, management, and interpretation of environmental data.
Design and evaluate strategies and technologies for sustainable management and restoration of the environment.

modules.title: Introduction to Innovation
topics: Definition and differentiation of creativity, invention, and innovation

topics: Understanding innovators and imitators in the innovation ecosystem

modules.title: Introduction to Entrepreneurship
topics: Entrepreneurship in a global context: role in social and economic development

topics: Concept and importance of social entrepreneurship

modules.title: Fundamentals of Managerial Economics and Demand Analysis
topics: Fundamental concepts of managerial economics
Objectives of the firm and the environment of business

modules.title: Production, Cost, and Pricing Decisions
topics: Production decisions and firm behaviour in short and long run

modules.title: Monetary and Fiscal Policy Framework

modules.title: Introduction, System Structure, Processes and Threads
topics: Introduction to Operating Systems: functions, evaluation, and importance in computing

System structure: computer system operation, I/O structure, storage structure and hierarchy
Protection mechanisms and operating system structures – simple, layered, and virtual machine models
Operating system services and system calls
Concept of processes and operations on processes – creation, maintenance, termination, scheduling, and communication
Threads: overview, benefits, user-level and kernel-level threads, and multithreading models

modules.title: Process Scheduling, Synchronization, and Deadlocks
topics: Process scheduling and inter-process communication in cooperative systems
CPU scheduling: scheduling criteria and types (preemptive and non-preemptive)

modules.title: Memory and Disk Management
topics: Memory management concepts: logical vs. physical address space, swapping, and contiguous memory allocation
Paging, segmentation, and segmentation with paging techniques

modules.title: File Systems, I/O Management, Protection and Security
topics: File systems: concept, access methods, and directory structures
File system structure and allocation methods: contiguous, linked, and indexed allocation
Free-space management: bit vector, linked list, grouping, and counting methods
Directory implementation: linear list and hash table; file system performance considerations
I/O management: I/O hardware, polling, interrupts, DMA, and device interfaces (block and character devices, clocks, and network devices)
Kernel I/O subsystem: scheduling, buffering, caching, spooling, device reservation, and error handling
Protection and security: goals of protection, domain of protection, authentication, and one-time passwords
Security threats: program and system threats, threat monitoring, and encryption techniques

courseOutcomes: Differentiate between various types of operating systems based on their design and applications.
